facts.text: The first respondent, a company registered under the Companies Act, filed a Writ petition in the High Court of Gujarat.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent, a companypany registered under the Companies Act, filed a Writ petition in the High Court of Gujarat. In that petition it impugned the provisions of sections 3, 6A and 7 of the Bombay Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953  hereinafter referred to as the Act  and s. 13 of the Bombay Labour Welfare Fund  Gujarat Extension and Amendment  Act, 1961  hereinafter referred to as the First Amendment Act  and rules 3 and 4 of the Bombay Labour Welfare Fund Rules, 1953  hereinafter referred to as tie Rules  as unconstitutional

facts.text: The writ petition impugned sections 3, 6A and 7 of the Bombay Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953, s.13 of the First Amendment Act 1961, and rules 3 and 4 of the Rules as unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: In that petition it impugned the provisions of sections 3, 6A and 7 of the Bombay Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953  hereinafter referred to as the Act  and s. 13 of the Bombay Labour Welfare Fund  Gujarat Extension and Amendment  Act, 1961  hereinafter referred to as the First Amendment Act  and rules 3 and 4 of the Bombay Labour Welfare Fund Rules, 1953  hereinafter referred to as tie Rules  as unconstitutional and prayed for the issue of a writ in the nature of mandamus or other appropriate writ or direction against the respondents in the writ petition to desist from enforcing the direction in the I numberice dated August 2, 1962

facts.text: Notice dated August 2, 1962 issued by respondent No. 3 requiring the petitioner (first respondent) to pay unpaid accumulations.

anchor.surface_text: to desist from enforcing the direction in the I numberice dated August 2, 1962 of respondent No. 3 to the writ petition requiring the petitioner-1st respondent to pay the unpaid accumulations specified therein.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court held s.3(1) of the Act insofar as it relates to unpaid accumulations in s.3(2)(b), s.3(4) and s.6A, and rules 3 and 4 unconstitutional and void.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that s. 3  1  of the Act in so far as it relates to unpaid accumulations specified in s. 3  2   b , s. 3  4  and s. 6A of the Act and rules 3 and 4 of the Rules was unconstitutional and void.

facts.text: Bombay Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953 passed by legislature of State of Bombay to constitute fund for labour welfare.

anchor.surface_text: In order to appreciate the companytroversy, it is necessary to state the background of the amendment made by the Legislature of Gujarat in the Act. The Act was passed by the legislature of the then State of Bombay in 1953 with a view to provide for the companystitution of a fund for financing the activities for promoting the welfare of labour in the State of Bombay.

facts.text: Section 2(10) of the Act defines unpaid accumulations as payments due to employees not made within 3 years.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 10  of the Act defined unpaid accumlation as meaning all payments due to the employees but number made to .them within a period of three years from the date on which they became due, whether before or after the companymencement of the Act, including the wages and gratuity legally payable, but number including the amount of companytribution, if any, paid by any employer to a Provident Fund established under the Employees Provident Fund Act, 1952.

facts.text: In Bombay Dyeing & Mfg. Co. Ltd. v. State of Bombay (1958 SCR 1122), Supreme Court held ss.3(1) and 3(2)(b) invalid under Art.19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: In Bombay Dyeing Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. The State of Bombay and Others 1  this Court held that the provisions of sections 3 1  and 3 2  b  were invalid on the ground that they violated the fundamental right of the employer under article 19 1  f .

facts.text: State of Bombay bifurcated into Maharashtra and Gujarat on May 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On May 1, 1960, the State of Bombay was bifurcated into the States of Maharashtra and Gujarat.

facts.text: Gujarat Legislature enacted First Amendment Act in 1961 with retrospective effect to remedy defects from Bombay Dyeing case.

anchor.surface_text: The legislature of Gujarat thereafter enacted to First Amendment Act making various amendments in the Act, some of them with retrospective effect. The First Amendment Act was intended to remedy the defects pointed out in the decision of this Court in the Bombay Dyeing Case 1 .

facts.text: Bombay Labour Welfare Fund (Gujarat Amendment) Act, 1962 passed on February 5, 1963, introducing s.6A(13) retrospectively.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the writ petition before the High Court, the Gujarat Legislature passed the Bombay Labour Welfare Fund  Gujarat Amendment  Act, 1962 on February 5, 1963  hereinafter referred to as the Second Amendment Act  introducing subsection  13  in s.6A with retrospective effect from the date of companymencement of the Act.

facts.text: High Court rejected most contentions of first respondent except two: violation of Art.19(1)(f) and discrimination in definition of 'establishment' under Art.14.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent raised several companytentions before the High Court, but the Court rejected all except two of them and they were  1  that the impugned provisions violated the fundamental right of citizen-employers and employees under article 19 1   f  and, therefore, the provisions were void under article 13 2  of the Constitution

facts.text: Definition of 'establishment' in s.2(4) includes factories, tramway/motor omnibus services, and establishments employing >50 persons, excludes govt establishments other than factories.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 4  Establishment means A factory A Tramway or motor omnibus service and Any establishment including a society registered under the Societies Registration Act, 1960, and a charitable or other trust, whether registered under the Bombay Public Trusts Act, 1950, or number, which carries on any business or trade or any work in companynection with or ancillary thereto and which employs or on any working day during the preceding twelve months employed more than fifty persons but does number include an establishment  number being a factory  of the Central or any State Government.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds impugned provisions do not violate Art.19(1)(f) for non-citizens like companies; law valid as to non-citizens.

anchor.surface_text: A Corporation is number a citizen for the purposes of article 19 and has, therefore, numberfundamental right under that article  see Tata Engineering and Locomotive Co. Ltd. v. State of Bihar and others 2 , R. C. Cooper v. Union of India 3 .

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds definition of 'establishment' under Art.14 as reasonable classification based on administrative convenience and labour turnover.

anchor.surface_text: The affidavit of Mr. Brahmbhatt made it clear that there were hardly any establishments of the Central or State Governments which carried on business or trade or any work in companynection with or ancillary thereto and, therefore, the legislature did number think it fit to extend the provisions of the Act to such establishments.

article 19 1  f . The reasoning of the Court was that the effect of the relevant provisions of the Act was to transfer to the Board the debts due by the employer to the employees free from the bar of limitation without discharging the employer from his liability to the employees and that s.3 1  therefore operated to take away the moneys of the employer without releasing him from his liability to the employees.

concepts.interpretation: Provisions requiring payment of unpaid accumulations to welfare fund violate employers' right to property under Art.19(1)(f) as they transfer debts without discharging liability and without adjudication machinery.

anchor.surface_text: In Bombay Dyeing Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. The State of Bombay and Others 1  this Court held that the provisions of sections 3 1  and 3 2  b  were invalid on the ground that they violated the fundamental right of the employer under article 19 1  f . The reasoning of the Court was that the effect of the relevant provisions of the Act was to transfer to the Board the debts due by the employer to the employees free from the bar of limitation without discharging the employer from his liability to the employees

arguments.court_reasoning: Defects remedied by retrospective amendments introducing s.6A machinery

holdings.text: A corporation is not a citizen for the purposes of article 19 and has, therefore, no fundamental right under that article.

anchor.surface_text: It is settled by the decisions of this Court that a Corporation is number a citizen for the purposes of article 19 and has, therefore, numberfundamental right under that article  see Tata Engineering and Locomotive Co. Ltd. v. State of Bihar and others 2 , R. C. Cooper v. Union of India 3 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows settled precedents like Tata Engineering and R.C. Cooper.

holdings.text: Even if a post-Constitution law takes away or abridges the fundamental right of citizens under article 19(1)(f), it is not void and non-est as respects non-citizens; it remains valid and operative qua non-citizens.

anchor.surface_text: The real question, therefore, is, even if a law takes away or abridges the fundamental right of citizens under article 19  1   f  I whether it would be void and therefore number-est as respects number-citizens ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 13(2) renders law void only to the extent of contravention of rights conferred on persons (citizens); synthesizes pre- and post-Constitution cases distinguishing eclipse doctrine.

holdings.text: The first respondent (non-citizen company) is not competent to challenge the impugned provisions as void on the ground that they violate Art.19(1)(f) of citizen-employers or employees, as the law is valid qua non-citizens.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, even assuming that under article 226 of the Constitution, the first respondent was entitled to move the High Court and seek, a remedy for infringement of its ordinary right to property, the impugned provisions were number number-est but were valid laws enacted by a companypetent legislature as respects number-citizens

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-citizens cannot invoke voidness qua citizens; law authorizes action against non-citizens; no infringement without authority of law.

holdings.text: The definition of 'establishment' in s.2(4) does not violate article 14; the classification is reasonable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification based on factories (>labour turnover, records), >50 employees (admin convenience), tramways/omnibuses (similar); excludes small/govt non-factories (negligible accumulations, few govt); rational nexus to collecting unpaid accumulations.

holdings.text: The 7-year period for claiming unpaid accumulations is reasonable and does not infringe constitutional rights.

anchor.surface_text: We think that if unpaid accumulations are number claimed within a total period of 7 years, the inactivity on the part of the employees would furnish adequate basis for the administration by State of the unasserted claims or demands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inactivity justifies state administration; not unreasonably short.

holdings.text: The notice procedure under s.6A complies with natural justice and provides sufficient information to employees.

anchor.surface_text: As regards numberice, we are of the view that all persons having property located within a state and subject to its dominion must take numbere of its statutes affecting companytrol and disposition of such property and the procedure prescribed for these, purposes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public notice, publication, affixing sufficient for reasonable information.

holdings.text: Doctrine of eclipse applies only to pre-Constitution laws, not post-Constitution laws violating fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: by the application of the doctrine of eclipse, the same result should flow in its case also.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes pre-Const (dormant, revivable) from post-Const (still-born qua affected persons).
